key_points: Vaccines are crucial in the fight against COVID-19, providing a safer alternative to infection for immunity.
Vaccines work by training the immune system to recognize and fight the virus without causing the disease.
People previously infected with SARS-CoV-2 are advised to get vaccinated to boost their immune response.
Post-vaccination, recipients should stay at the vaccination site for 15–30 minutes for observation of possible reactions.
COVID-19 vaccines can have mild-to-moderate side effects, which typically resolve within a few days.
Some COVID-19 vaccines require two doses for maximum efficacy, with a recommended 21–28 day interval between doses, potentially extendable.
WHO advises using vaccines from the same manufacturer for both doses, with flexibility based on further evidence.
Clinical trials have shown COVID-19 vaccines to be safe and effective at preventing severe disease.
The longevity of protection and the potential of vaccinated individuals to transmit the virus are still under study.
Despite vaccine rollout, following recommended measures to reduce virus spread remains crucial.
